para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Wildlife and Heritage Service.
“Director” means the Director of the Wildlife and Heritage Service.

“Endangered extirpated species” means any species that was once a viable component of the flora or fauna of the State but for which no naturally occurring populations are known to exist in the State. Most of these species have not been recorded in Maryland since 1950.

“Endangered species” means any species whose continued existence as a viable component of the State's flora or fauna is determined to be in jeopardy including any species determined to be an "endangered species" pursuant to the federal Endangered Species Act of 1973, 16 U.S.C. §§1531—1543.

“Harass” means an intentional or negligent act or omission which creates the likelihood of injury to wildlife by annoying wildlife to an extent that significantly disrupts normal behavioral patterns which include, but are not limited to, breeding, feeding, or sheltering.
“Harm” means an act which kills or injures wildlife.

Harm includes an act that significantly modifies or degrades a habitat thereby killing or injuring wildlife by significantly impairing essential behavioral patterns, including breeding, feeding, or sheltering.
“Incidental taking” means takings of listed species that are incidental to, and not the purpose of, the carrying out of an otherwise lawful activity conducted by a person on private property.

“Jeopardize the continued existence of” means to engage in an action which reasonably would be expected, directly or indirectly, to reduce appreciably the likelihood of either the survival or recovery of a listed species in the wild by reducing the reproduction, numbers, or distribution of a listed species or otherwise adversely affecting the species.
“Listed species” means a species of flora or fauna deemed endangered, threatened or in need of conservation in this chapter due to any of the following factors:
Present or threatened destruction, modification, or curtailment of the species' habitat or range;
Overutilization for commercial, sporting, scientific, educational, or other purposes;
Inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms; or
Other natural or manmade factors affecting the species' continued existence within the State.
“Natural heritage area” means any natural community of species designated in Regulation .10 in this chapter.

“Person” means any county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State, an individual, corporation, receiver, trustee, guardian, executor, administrator, fiduciary, or representative.
“Site” is property or properties, owned singularly or in combination, that support threatened or endangered species.

“Species” means any species of wildlife or plant and reptiles, amphibians, crustaceans, mollusks, and the following finfish: Acipenser brevirostrum, Acipenser oxyrinchus, Alburnops chalybaeus, Catostomus catostomus, Centrarchus macropterus, Enneacanthus chaetodon, Etheostoma sellare, Etheostoma vitreum, Lethenteron appendix, Luxilus chrysocephalus, Margariscus margarita, Notropis bifrenatus, Noturus flavus, Pararhinichthys bowersi, Percina bimaculata, Percina notogramma, Percopsis omiscomaycus, or any part, egg, offspring, or dead body of any of them.
“Species in need of conservation” means any species determined by the Secretary to be in need of conservation measures for its continued ability to sustain itself successfully.
“Take” means to harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect, or attempt to engage in any such conduct.

“Threatened species” means any species of flora or fauna which appears likely, within the foreseeable future, to become endangered including any species determined to be a "threatened species" pursuant to the federal Endangered Species Act of 1973, 16 U.S.C. §§1531—1543.

Except for species determined to be threatened or endangered pursuant to the federal Endangered Species Act of 1973, 16 U.S.C. §§1531—1543, any interested person may petition the Director to add or remove a species or natural heritage area to or from a list in this chapter. The Director shall review the evidence regarding the requested action and make a recommendation to the Secretary whether or not to list or delist the species or natural heritage area.
In a petition to list or delist a natural heritage area, the following information shall be provided:
A map of the proposed natural heritage area;
A description of the physical boundaries of the proposed area, total acreage, landowner name and address;

A description of the biological community represented by the natural heritage area including, as far as practical, a list of the fauna and flora there, and other geologic, hydrologic, or other features which blend together to make this area unique;

A description of all major threats to the continued existence of the area, or if petitioning to delist an area, a description of how the natural features and species composition of the area have changed so it is no longer suitable to be designated as a natural heritage area;
A statement indicating why the area should or should not be considered as among the best statewide examples of its kind;
Other relevant information which might assist the Director in making a determination.

All sites used for evidence of current abundance shall be extant and all sitings shall be documented with appropriate vouchers. In a petition to list or delist a species, the following information shall be provided:
A description of the biological distribution of the species in Maryland.
Its life needs and habitat requirements.
Evidence of its decline or evidence that it is more common than previously believed and documented.
All known threats which jeopardize its continued existence.
Other relevant biological and ecological data or other life history information pertinent to its status.

The species shall be presently recognized as a valid species, or infraspecific taxa of regional or national significance. There shall be adequate documentation that it occurs naturally and is permanently established in Maryland.

Permits to take, transport, possess, sell, offer for sale, export or import any listed species may be obtained from the Director only after written application on a form provided by the Administration, and upon payment of a fee of $10.
Each permit shall be subject to an expiration date and other limitations as may be prescribed by the Director.

Each permit application requesting permission to take a listed species from private property shall be accompanied by a signed statement from the landowner granting the applicant permission to enter the property to take the species.
A permit application shall describe the purpose of the request in such detail that the Director can determine whether it is in the best interest of the species and the State to issue it.
The Director shall consider, but not be limited to, the following information:
The number of other known occurrences of the species in the State;
Which of the occurrences of the species in §E(1) exist on:
What protection there is for the species' continued existence;
The number of individuals in the occurrences of the species in §E(1) and the relative state of ecological stability.

Violation of any provision or restriction of the permit shall constitute a violation of this regulation and may result, at the discretion of the Director, in the revocation of the permit and confiscation of the species taken or possessed.

section.heading: Endangered Species of Wildlife, Reptiles, Amphibians, Mollusks, Crustaceans, and Finfish.

para.text: Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing any species other than plants as endangered:
Whether the species is restricted to a minimal geographic area within Maryland;
Whether the species has experienced a rapid, substantial decline in Maryland, and if the decline continues, the species' extirpation from Maryland is imminent;
Whether the species' essential habitat has been rapidly lost and that loss is likely to continue;
Whether the species' biology makes it highly susceptible to changes in its environment; or
Whether the species' essential habitat is easily altered by even relatively minor activities.
Permits. The permit procedures to be followed are set forth in Regulation .03. The following apply:
Permits shall be issued only for:
Scientific research designed to enhance the recovery of the species or population, or
Appropriate educational purposes designed to further public awareness regarding the species;

A person may not take, export, possess, process, sell or offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport, or ship by any means any endangered wildlife, reptile, amphibian, mollusk, crustacean, or finfish species except by special permit from the Director.

Except for the smaller range which is indicated in §C(7)(d) and (8)(a) of this regulation, the following wildlife, reptile, amphibian, mollusk, crustacean, and finfish species are considered endangered throughout Maryland:
Blue Ridge spring snail (Fontigens orolibas); and
Seth Forest water scavenger beetle (Hydrochus spangleri);
Northern map turtle (Graptemys geographica) — Susquehanna River watershed only;
American goshawk (Accipiter atricapillus)—Garrett and Allegany Counties only;
Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing a plant species as endangered:
Whether only a few populations are known in Maryland and they cover only a small portion of land;
Whether the species is restricted to a minimal geographic area;
Whether the species has experienced a substantial decline in Maryland, and if the decline continues, the species extirpation from Maryland is imminent;
Whether the species’ essential habitat has been rapidly lost and that loss is likely to continue;
Whether the species’ biology makes it highly susceptible to changes in its environment; or
Whether the species’ essential habitat is easily altered by even relatively minor activities.
Permits. The permit procedures to be followed are set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter. The following apply:
Permits shall be issued only for scientific research designed to enhance the recovery of the species or population;

Export, possess, process, sell, offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport, or ship by any means any endangered plant species without a special permit from the Director, the federal government, or another state government;
Take any endangered plant species from State property except by special permit from the Director; and
Take any endangered plant species from private property without the written permission of the landowner.
The following plant species are considered endangered throughout Maryland unless a smaller range is indicated:
Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing a species as endangered extirpated:
The species was once a viable component of the State’s flora and fauna and there are no records of it naturally occurring in Maryland after 1950; or
The species was once a viable component of the State’s flora and fauna and recent scientific investigations have documented the loss of its habitat or disappearance of its population in Maryland.

Permits. Upon the discovery of a viable, naturally occurring population of any species in §§C—J of this regulation, that species shall be considered an endangered species and shall require the permits and conditions afforded to that status.
The following plant species are considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland:
The following mollusk species is considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland: Maryland glyph (Glyphyalinia raderi).
The following crustacean species is considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland: Norden’s groundwater isopod (Caecidotea nordeni).
The following insect species are considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland:
The following finfish species are considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland:
The following amphibian species is considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland: Common mudpuppy (Necturus maculosus).
The following bird species are considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland:
Appalachian Bewick’s wren (Thryomanes bewickii bewickii); and
The following mammal species are considered endangered extirpated throughout Maryland:

section.heading: Threatened Species of Wildlife, Reptiles, Amphibians, Mollusks, Crustaceans, and Finfish.

para.text: Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing species other than plant species as threatened:
Whether the species has experienced a steady, substantial decline in Maryland, and if the decline continues, the species is likely to become endangered;
Whether there has been steady, widespread loss of the species' essential habitat; or
Whether protection measures already taken have significantly reduced the chances of the species becoming extirpated from Maryland.
Permits. The permit procedures to be followed are set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter. The following apply:

Except by special permit from the Director, a person may not take, export, possess, process, sell, offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport or ship by any means any threatened wildlife, reptile, amphibian, mollusk, crustacean, or finfish species.
Permits to take threatened species shall be issued only for:
Scientific research designed to enhance the recovery of the species or population;
Educational purposes designed to further public awareness regarding the species.

Incidental taking of a threatened wildlife, reptile, amphibian, mollusk, crustacean, or finfish species shall be allowed only after the Director has been notified 30 days in advance of the change in land use or other action by a private landowner which shall result in the incidental taking. The Administration, upon receipt of the application for an incidental taking permit from the landowner, shall within 30 days either:
Take action to salvage the threatened species; or
Issue to the landowner an incidental taking permit authorizing the landowner to proceed with the action which will result in the incidental taking of the species.
The following species are considered to be threatened throughout Maryland unless a smaller range is indicated:
Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing a plant species as threatened:
Whether the species has experienced a substantial decline in Maryland, and if the decline continues, the species is likely to become endangered;
Whether there has been a steady widespread loss of the species’ essential habitat; or
Whether the species has been listed as endangered but it has been shown that protection measures taken have significantly reduced the chances of the species becoming extirpated from Maryland.
Permits. The permit procedures to be followed are set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter. The following apply:
Permits shall be issued only for scientific research designed to enhance the recovery of the species or population;
Export, possess, process, sell, offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport, or ship by any means any threatened plant species except by a special permit from the Director;
Take any threatened plant species from State property except by special permit from the Director; or
Take any threatened plant species from private property without the written permission of the landowner.
The following plant species are considered threatened throughout Maryland unless a smaller range is indicated:
Listing Criteria. The following factors shall be considered for listing a species as in need of conservation:
Whether the population is limited or declining within Maryland; and
Whether the species may become threatened in the foreseeable future, if current trends or conditions persist.
Permits. The permit procedures to be followed are set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter. The following apply:
Except by special permit, a person may not take, export, possess, process, sell, offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport, or ship by any means any species in need of conservation;
Permits to take species in need of conservation shall be issued only for:
Scientific research designed to enhance the recovery of the species or population;
Educational purposes designed to further public awareness regarding the species.
Incidental taking permits are not required for species in need of conservation.
The following species are considered to be in need of conservation throughout Maryland unless a smaller range is indicated:
Coastal Plain swamp sparrow (Melospiza georgiana nigrescens);
Listing Criteria. In order to qualify as a natural heritage area a natural community shall:
Contain one or more threatened or endangered species or wildlife species in need of conservation;
Be a unique blend of geological, hydrological, climatalogical or biological features; and
Be considered to be among the best Statewide examples of its kind.

The Administration shall prepare maps describing the location of all natural heritage areas. The maps shall be filed in the office of the Director of the Wildlife and Heritage Service, Department of Natural Resources, Tawes State Office Building, Annapolis, MD 21401.
The following areas are designated natural heritage areas:

tr.td: (24) Upper Nanticoke River, Marshes and Swamps

para.text: Without written permission from the Secretary, a person may not trespass, enter, or release an animal on lands owned or controlled by the State which are located between the mean high and mean low water lines of waters of the State and which are posted in a conspicuous manner as a restricted area for the purpose of protecting:
An endangered or threatened species of wildlife or plant listed in this chapter; or
A species of wildlife in need of conservation listed in this chapter.

The Department shall prepare maps describing the location of each restricted area under this regulation. The maps shall be filed with the Secretary of Natural Resources, Tawes State Office Building, Annapolis, Maryland 21401.
A restricted area may be established only after:
Notice of the proposed restriction has been placed in a newspaper in the county where the restriction is proposed;
Notice of the proposed restriction has been placed in the Maryland Register;
Completion of a 30-day period for comment which begins on the date that the list of restricted areas is published in the Maryland Register;
All adjacent landowners have been notified by mail of the proposal; and
Appropriate areas have been signed and posted.
The delineation of restricted areas may change to accommodate changes in the distribution of listed species after the notice provisions of §C of this regulation have been satisfied.

In Calvert County, the restricted areas encompass that portion of the lands owned or controlled by the State which are located between the mean high and mean low water lines of the waters of the State adjacent to Flag Ponds Nature Park.

In Worcester County, the restricted areas encompass that portion of the lands owned or controlled by the State which are located between the mean high and mean low water lines of the waters of the State adjacent to:
The shoreline of Skimmer Island in Isle of Wight Bay.

section.heading: Additional Lists.
section.text: The Fisheries Service also maintains a list of fish species that are designated as endangered, threatened, or in need of conservation under COMAR 08.02.12. Regulations implementing protective measures for these species appear elsewhere under COMAR 08.02.

section.heading: Violation of Regulations.
section.text: Violation of these regulations is a misdemeanor punishable under Natural Resources Article, §§10-2A-07, 10-1101, 10-1105—10-1108, 4-2A-07, 4-1201, 4-1205—4-1207, and 4-1209, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: Permit Required. A person shall obtain a permit from the Department before the person may conduct any activity that will result in the incidental taking of Puritan tiger beetles.
Application. To apply for a permit for the incidental taking of Puritan tiger beetles, an applicant shall submit the following information to the Department:
A completed application form including the applicant's:
A conservation plan for the site that shall include the following:
Site location information, including tax map and parcel numbers;
A map of the site, including property boundaries, location of the cliff, and location of the proposed development;
A description of proposed habitat alteration, including physical alteration of beach or cliff habitat;
A description of alternatives considered and reasons that these alternatives were not used;
A description of minimization and mitigation measures to be employed; and
A copy of the submitted federal application or approved federal authorization from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to incidentally take Puritan tiger beetles.

Permit applications may be obtained from the Wildlife and Heritage Service, Tawes State Office Building, 580 Taylor Ave., E-1, Annapolis, Maryland 21401, or by calling 410-260-8540, or online at www.dnr.state.md.us.
Completed applications shall be mailed or delivered to: Permits Coordinator, Wildlife and Heritage Service, Tawes State Office Building, 580 Taylor Ave., E-1, Annapolis, Maryland 21401.
Duration. Permits for the incidental taking of Puritan tiger beetles are valid for the term specified by the Department on the permit.
Minimization measures as described in §B(2)(e) of this regulation shall include:
Limiting construction activities during the adult breeding season of June through August in order to minimize adult tiger beetle mortality;
Limiting construction activities to the beach area and no alteration of the cliff face;
Limiting habitat alteration to a portion of the tiger beetle habitat; and
Limiting other actions that harm adult Puritan tiger beetles, larvae, or habitat.
Mitigation shall be employed whenever the habitat alteration will render a significant portion of the site unsuitable for Puritan tiger beetles in either their adult or larval life forms.
Mitigation shall occur at not less than a 1:1 ratio of linear feet of shoreline impacted.

Protection of other property suitable for Puritan tiger beetle habitat by acquisition of a conservation easement that permanently prohibits shoreline stabilization of or alteration of the cliff face on the property;
Payment of any mitigation fee that may be required through the federal permitting process;
Restoration or creation of Puritan tiger beetle habitat by participating financially in the Department's Puritan tiger beetle habitat conservation program; and
Implementation of other measures that compensate for the loss of Puritan tiger beetles as a result of the incidental taking.
A conservation easement under §G(3)(a) of this regulation shall be executed and recorded before the issuance of an incidental taking permit.
The Department shall issue an incidental taking permit to the applicant if all of the following have been satisfied:
The applicant has submitted the completed application form, fee, and conservation plan;
Alternatives have been considered and determined not to be feasible;
Adequate minimization or mitigation measures have been incorporated into the habitat conservation plan;
The actions do not appreciably reduce the likelihood of the survival or recovery of the Puritan tiger beetle;
Adequate funding for the conservation plan is available to implement the plan; and
Federal authorization to incidentally take Puritan tiger beetles has been secured by the applicant from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

A person may not take, export, possess, process, sell, offer for sale, deliver, carry, transport, or ship by any means, except by special permit issued by the Department, nongame mammals listed in §C of this regulation.
Permits to take protected nongame mammals may only be issued for:
Educational purposes designed to further public awareness regarding the species;
Protection of human health and safety; or
Incidental taking permits are not required for protected nongame mammals.
The following species are considered to be protected nongame mammals:

Regulations .01 and .02 were previously codified as Regulations .43 and .65, respectively, under COMAR 08.03.01 Wildlife Conservation. This recodification was effective June 3, 1985 (12:11 Md. R. 1047)
For the history of these regulations before June 3, 1985, see the Administrative History which follows COMAR 08.03.01.
